choices: blood acidity is reduced by excessive breathing.
slow, shallow breathing eliminates too much carbon dioxide.
the level of carbon dioxide in the blood increases.
dangerous acids accumulate in the bloodstream.
front.question: Alkalosis is a condition that occurs when:

cards.back: blood acidity is reduced by excessive breathing.

front.question: In what area of the lungs does respiration occur?
front.source: See Anatomy of the Respiratory System

choices: a complete cessation of respiratory effort.
labored breathing with reduced tidal volume.
shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.
a marked increase in the exhalation phase.
front.question: Dyspnea is MOST accurately defined as:

cards.back: shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.

choices: there must be low quantities of pulmonary surfactant to allow for full alveolar expansion.
the percentage of inhaled carbon dioxide must exceed the percentage of inhaled oxygen.
oxygen and carbon dioxide must be able to freely diffuse across the alveolar–capillary membrane.
the pulmonary capillaries must be completely constricted and the alveoli must be collapsed.
front.question: In order for efficient pulmonary gas exchange to occur:

cards.back: oxygen and carbon dioxide must be able to freely diffuse across the alveolar–capillary membrane.

choices: respirations decrease in rate and depth.
respirations increase in rate and depth.
front.question: When the level of arterial carbon dioxide rises above normal:

cards.back: respirations increase in rate and depth.

choices: The pulse oximeter is a valuable assessment tool that measures the percentage of red blood cells that contain hemoglobin molecules.
Most otherwise healthy patients can maintain adequate oxygenation and good skin color with oxygen saturation readings as low as 70% to 80%.
Caution must be exercised when using the pulse oximeter on a patient with carbon monoxide poisoning because falsely low readings are common.
Pulse oximetry measures the percentage of hemoglobin that is saturated with oxygen but does not measure the actual hemoglobin content of the blood.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding pulse oximetry is correct?

cards.back: Pulse oximetry measures the percentage of hemoglobin that is saturated with oxygen but does not measure the actual hemoglobin content of the blood.

choices: place her in a recumbent position to facilitate breathing.
determine if she has been prescribed a beta-agonist inhaler.
call medical control and ask how to proceed with treatment.
contact medical control and administer an antihistamine.
front.question: A conscious and alert 29-year-old female with a history of asthma complains of difficulty breathing that began after her morning jog. The temperature outside is 40°F (5°C). On exam, you hear bilateral expiratory wheezing. After providing supplemental oxygen, you should:

cards.back: determine if she has been prescribed a beta-agonist inhaler.

choices: start at the lower lung fields and determine at which level you start hearing clear breath sounds.
pay special attention to the exhalation phase because this is when you will likely hear rales or rhonchi.
note the presence of a high-pitched whistling sound, which is an indicator of fluid in the lungs.
auscultate the posterior chest first and compare the apex of one lung to the base of the opposite lung.
front.question: When assessing for fluid collection in the lungs during auscultation of lung sounds, you should:

cards.back: start at the lower lung fields and determine at which level you start hearing clear breath sounds.

choices: a bacterial infection of the lung tissue.
front.question: A pleural effusion is MOST accurately defined as:

Asthma is caused by a response of the:
When auscultating the lungs of a patient with respiratory distress, you hear adventitious sounds. This means that the patient has:
Harsh, high-pitched inspiratory sounds are characteristic of:

choices: 30 breaths/min with supraclavicular retractions and clammy skin
22 breaths/min with an irregular pattern of breathing and cyanosis
20 breaths/min with shallow movement of the chest wall and pallor
24 breaths/min with bilaterally equal breath sounds and pink skin
front.question: Which of the following is MOST characteristic of adequate breathing?

cards.back: 24 breaths/min with bilaterally equal breath sounds and pink skin

front.question: Hyperventilation could be associated with all of the following, EXCEPT:

choices: tachypnea and tingling in the extremities.
front.question: Common signs and symptoms of acute hyperventilation syndrome include:

cards.back: tachypnea and tingling in the extremities.

front.question: Which of the following conditions would be LEAST likely to result in hypoxia?
